labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Add outline of Security Considerations Topics/sub-sections
issues.author: rahelFain
issues.body:
Provide an outline of the topics that will be discussed in this document. 
This could also include a statement noting that use case specific security considerations will need to be specified in their protocol specification document(s).

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body:
I began thinking of a few topics that could be included in the Security Considerations Section - but have listed them in this issue rather than a PR b/c I still have yet to discuss these with my co-authors. 

Potential Entries subsections to include:

1. Digital Emblems do not actively stop/defend against attacks: For emblems that indicate an asset's protected status, digital emblems can at best serve as a deterrent for attack - as there is no guarantee a would-be attacker will respect the laws, agreements or standards granting the asset its status. 

2. Plausible deniability surrounding whether or not emblem was seen, visible or verifiable at time of validation.

Note: This is by no means intended to be an exhaustive list of topics but rather a first brainstorm.

comments.author: amankin
comments.body: 3. For Digital Emblems that require Authentication of the Digital Emblem, origin authentication or other authentication of the Bearer, or Authorization of the Digital Emblem (the MUSTs in Section 3),  the threat model addressed is presentation of falsified Digital Emblems. Both 1 and 2 above will require addressing this threat model.

pulls.title: Add charter definitions
pulls.author: rahelFain
pulls.body: Explicitly adds the definitions for terms "(digital) emblem," bearer" and "validations" from the current charter.

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body: Response to feedback that the definitions in the charter could change in the event that the DIEM WG is rechartered sometime in the future.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
Thanks for preparing, @rahelFain, and iterating, @rohanmahy!

I must say, I don't like the "definition" of (digital) emblems in the charter. I don't find it to define anything. In the charter, this is not a problem, because we don't say: "Look, here we define what an emblem is." It's informal and glue text. This changes, however, if we copy-paste these passages into the document.

Let's look at what the definition says from a more abstract point of view:

> Emblems such as [...] can be [X]. Emblems can also be [Y].

The three sentences after that are more a problem statement that I would rather keep in the charter. These two sentences don't define anything, they only give examples of emblems.

Personally, I have two, contradictory goals:

- Have unambiguous terminology.
- Don't spend much time discussing what "digital emblems" are.

We already spent a long time during chartering trying to define digital emblems, and my feeling is that little came out of that. And I would rather sacrifice ambiguous terminology than having to spent a long time defining digital emblems.

What do you think? Is it really necessary to have a definition of digital emblems that encompass everything ever brought to the WG?

comments.author: rahelFain
comments.body:
@felixlinker My intent in adding the definition text was not necessarily to state that this was the official definition, but rather to have the referenced text explicitly copied here so that it could be referenced even if the charter were to change. (Hence the comments noting that the text is copy-pasted from the current version of the charter.) 
I'd be willing to call this something less firm than a set of definitions (say for example descriptions) and to add a caveat that later documents may more precisely define these terms - and that the sole reason for including this text was to ensure document clarity.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body: If we move the text on DEs into the intro, that could work, for example. Just wanted to make clear that I think we should stay away from defining the term "DE." It' sa rabbit hole that we just got out off (chartering) :)

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> If we move the text on DEs into the intro, that could work, for example. Just wanted to make clear that I think we should stay away from defining the term "DE." It' sa rabbit hole that we just got out off (chartering) :)

You could also use terms like "working definition" or "temporary definition" for now.

comments.author: felixlinker
comments.body:
> You could also use terms like "working definition" or "temporary definition" for now.

"Working definition" maybe, but "temporary" suggests we may want to revisit it. I think we shouldn't. This will just distract the working group without any benefit.

```suggestion
The definitions for terms "(digital) emblem," "bearer," and "validation" are reproduced from the charter {{CHARTER}} as of this writing.
```

"current" is redundant and eventually wrong..

```suggestion
```

This is no longer relevant since you have them in the next section.

```suggestion
```

These seem like requirements instead of part of the definition of "validation"

```suggestion
(Digital) Emblem:
: Emblems such as the Red Cross, Red Crescent, Red Crystal, and Blue Shield can be symbols of protection governed by International Humanitarian Law (IHL).
  Emblems can also be identified by other laws, agreements, or standards.
  There is a need to present emblems through digital communication channels.
  Emblems presented in such ways are called digital emblems.
  Digital emblems extend the range of identifying marks from the physical (visual and tactile) to the digital realm.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

```suggestion
Bearer:
: "To bear an emblem" means to present and be identified by a digital emblem.
  The entity that bears the emblem is the bearer or emblem holder.
  This is often a separate entity from the creator or original designer of the emblem.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

```suggestion

Validation:
: "To validate an emblem" means to confirm the authenticity or legitimacy of a particular symbol or design,
often by checking its details against a known standard or reference point.
  Validation may include ensuring that the bearer has not forged, stolen, or tampered with an emblem.
  Emblems may be observed by validators without the knowledge of the bearer presenting the emblem, or may be presented to a specific validator upon request.
  Cryptographic verification may or may not be used based on the in-place security mechanisms of the communication channel bearing the emblem.
  Which attributes an emblem contains, and how a digital emblem is secured and presented impacts how a validator interprets and trusts the assertions made within the emblem.
```

Turn into a markdown definition

reviews.author: felixlinker
reviews.body:
For easier reference, here my opinion as a review. I think, we're best off not aiming to define the term "digital emblem." Defining that term will just be a rabit chase without any benefit.

If we simply drop references to that term in this PR, I'm good with merging it!

pulls.title: Ready to Submit draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00 ??
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body: If the authors are ready to submit draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00 after the draft submission pause, just merge this PR and manually submit versioned/draft-ietf-diem-requirements-00.xml.

pulls.title: Simpler phrasing of undetectable validation
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body: The old phrasing could have suggested that only *actual* bearers (and other parties) must not be able to detect validation. This is not what was intended. I now phrase undetectable validation w.r.t. to the discovery requirement. This should make it clear that also non-bearers must not be able to detect when someone is checking whether they are a bearer.
